titleStmt.title: Anatomical Atlases Based on Volume Visualization

analytic.title: Anatomical Atlases Based on Volume Visualization

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: In current practice computerized anatomical atlasses are based on a collection of images that can be accessed via a hypermedia program shell. Zn order t o overcome the drawback of a limited number of available views, we propose an approach that uses an anatomical model as data base. The model has a two layer structure. The lower level as a volume model with a set of semantic attributes belonging t o each voxel. Its spatial representation is derived f r o m data sets of Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Computer Tomogmphy. The semantic attributes are assigned by an anatomist using a volume editor. The upper level is a set of relations between these attributes which are specified by the expert as well. Interactive visualization tools such as multiple surface display, transparent rendering and cutting are provided. A s a substantial feature of the implementation the semantic and the visualization oriented descriptions are stored in a knowledge base. Zt is shown that the combination of this object oriented data structure with advanced volume visualization tools provides the "look and feel" of a real dissection. The concept which even allows simulations like surgery rehearsal, is claimed t o be superior t o all presently known atlas techniques.

div.head: 1: Introduction
div.p: Applications of volume visualization in medicine have recently developed rather quickly. While in the early beginnings the preferred technique was the visualization of isosurfaces [ l , 21, the availability of fast computers made true volume oriented methods possible [3-71. Medical applications deal mainly with therapy (especially surgery) planning based on tomographic data [8-lo]. Wide spread application suffers from the still unsolved problem of the automatic object identification in gray scale volumes. Although it lends itself perfectly to volume vizualization techniques, one application that has been widely overlooked, is medical education. It is the objective of this paper to present a framework for the generation of atlasses of the human body based on the linkage of volume data to a knowledge base.

div.head: 2: Earlier work
div.p: Over centuries medical students acquired their practical experience about human gross anatomy via dissection, while the theoretical background was gained from anatomy textbooks and atlasses. Anatomy is presented there by drawings and/or photographs with corresponding annotations. As compared to the possibilities of data organization in modern computers a book is a linear and particularly rigid structure in which the relations of all types of knowledge are fixed. With the development of hypermedia techniques in the past decade both pictorial and descriptive knowledge could be organized in such a way that random paths through the knowledge are possible depending on the teaching aim and the learner's needs [ll]. Still the underlying paradigm is that of a bookhypermedia screens mostly exhibit a set of pages, where especially the pictures are precomputed or digitized image matrices. Different aspects of the same object have to be present as different images.

It is obvious that by having computerized models of the objects this can be avoided and different pictorial representations can be created at the user's will. Computerized models of the human brain have been used for several purposes in the past. One purpose is the correlation of functional information e. g. from Positron-Emission Tomography (PET) with detailed structural information e. g. from MRI [12, 13, 141. A more academic application is the utilization of a computer model as knowledge base for experiments in computer vision [15]. Not much work has been done in the field of model based atlasses for medical education [16, 171. The projects described before have in common that the objects are re- presented as 2D or 3D contours. This object representation does not allow the "look and feel" of a dissection, which is the main process for exploring an anatomical object, because the objects are hollow. Cutting does thus not reveal realistic surfaces.

The approach presented here is therefore based on a complete volume model. It will be shown that, through the advanced realism of this model and the linkage of descriptive information novel educational applications can be generated, which include interactive dissection procedures.

div.head: 3.1: Basic Data Structure
div.p: The basic idea is to describe the anatomical object in a two level data structure ( fig. 1,2). The lower level contains the "generalized voxel model" Base [18]. This consists of an image volume having as a primary attribute an intensity value which can be derived from In addition each voxel contains attributes describing its membership to a semantic region. These regions can be:

The upper layer of the data structure is a knowledge base that contains relations between these regions in the form of trees or nets. These relationships may concern : 0 structure (e. g. precentral gyrus is part of the frontal lobe)

div.head: 3.2: Construction of the 3D-models
div.p: For our pilot system we use magnetic resonance (MRI) and computer tomographic (CT) data sets as basic image volumes. The original crosssectional images are interpolated t o achieve an image volume with cubic voxels. This is performed by linear scaling in the direction perpendicular t o the original slices.

The critical step is the assignment of the attributes t o sets of voxels. The most important one is the membership t o a structural region (e. g. a gyrus). This simple task is very tedious in practice and can only be performed using a set of specially designed tools. As first step a coarse semi-automatic segmentation into the gross anatomical components like the skull, brain or ventricular system is performed. For this purpose we used initially the method described by Bomans [19], now we are using exclusively interactive segmentation tools [20, 211. The accurate identification of voxels that belong to a region is performed by an anatomist using a volume editor. It allows standard editing procedures on 2D slices like thresholding, region filling, and pixel painting. However, with 2D techniques neither inter-slice object coherence nor the smoothness of surfaces can be assured. For this a 3D editing mode is provided that allows painting on any visible 3D surface with a depth that can be specified explicitly or by an intensity threshold. This painting procedure is used for the definition of objects or the correction of already existing ones.

In most cases combined application of both 2D and 3D tools leads t o the final goal. Thus, for example, the only way of reliably labelling a gyrus of a brain is to label the surface on a 3D view (like in fig. 3), while its spatial extent can be corrected on the thus labelled cross-sectional images.

Interestingly, not all anatomical items have a physical representation. Examples are the fissures between the gyri of a brain. For these objects we have provided a graphics objects table containing lists of coordinates resulting from polygons that are painted onto the visible surface by the neuroanatomist.
So far we have described the acquisition of vo-

xel sets, which form semantic regions. The result is an attribute volume for each region type (one Finally, problem oriented tools for the simulat i o n of medical procedures can be derived from the basic tools. Three of them are presently implemen t ed:

div.head: 3.3: Exploration Tools
div.p: simulation of surgery 0 simulation of the path of a stereotactic device simulation of X-ray images from computer tomographic volumes.

div.head: 3.4: I m p l e m e n t a t i o n
div.p: As shown in fig. 3 we have used MOTIF for designing the user interface. Interaction is performed either through menues or through a command language (which is also used by the menue interface). As a very useful byproduct of this construction the command sequence of an exploration session can be logged and can be run as a movie afterwards, if necessary after editing the sequence ( fig. 4). All code is written in C under UNIX. The program has been developed on a DECstation 5000/200 and is actually being ported t o the SUN SPARCstation 2. For the most frequently used exploration actions like coloring or annotation the reaction time is less than one second. For exploration actions like rotation and cutting it depends on the quality chosen. The small images in fig. 3 (256 x 256 image matrix) require about 5 second on a DECstation 5000/200, a quality which is sufficient in many instances. A high quality image such as the large one in fig. 3 (1017 x 604 image matrix) may take 10 minutes. The next generation of workstations will reduce these times substantially. Fig. 4 Command sequence produced by the user interface during an interactive session and its final result. Fig. 5 Artificial X-ray image (topogram) produced from the CT model. At the cursor position the relative contribution of the components to the final image can be inquired. In the inserted "scout view" the direction of the X-rays is depicted. Components (here the mandible) can be added at their proper location.

div.head: 4: Applications
div.p: So far we have developed first versions of atlasses of the brain and the skull, which are already in use. Atlasses of the abdomen, of a fetus, and a pelvic surgery atlas are under development. Generating a new atlas means the generation of a new knowledge base by segmentation and editing. The program shell stays the same for any application.

div.head: 4.1: Brain
div.p: An atlas of the human brain has been developed on the basis of an MR data set of 150x200~192 voxels. It contains 150 structural and 25 functional objects so far. An example is given in fig. 3.

div.head: 4.2: Skull
div.p: The atlas of the skull has been generated from a CT data set of 240x242~246 voxels. It contains presently 75 objects. One of its interesting features is the possibility of generating artificial X-ray images whose intensity values can be related to the imaged objects ( fig. 5).

div.head: 4.3: Abdomen
div.p: As a further project we have started to build an atlas of the abdominal region from a CT-spiral creen data set. First segmentation results can be found in [21].

div.head: 4.4: Fetus
div.p: Fetal anatomy is considerably different from that of adults. So it was considered important by our pediatric colleagues to have a 3D atlas of a fetus.
It is derived from a MR data set of 100x200~256 voxels ( fig. 6).

div.head: 4.6: Pelvic sugery
div.p: Complicated anatomical situations like pelvic fractures are difficult to assess from crosssectional or projection images. Our atlas concept allows the construction of 3D atlasses which allow the correlation of cross-sectional and projection imaging with the 3D anatomy. An atlas system, which contains a set of typical fractures is under

div.head: 5: Conclusions
div.p: It has been shown that a volume model linked to a knowledge base is a powerful data structure for constructing 3D anatomical atlasses. On one hand this is because it is well suited to visualization of both surface and volume properties of the anatomy. Thus it provides the look and feel which comes near to that of an actual dissection.

On the other hand this structure is flexible in that it easily allows the incorporation of extensions both on the level of the spatial regions and the relational descriptions. It has to be admitted that 3D-editing of the spatial primitives is a tedious task, but it needs to be done only oncefor a specimen. This can then be used ip a virtually unlimited number of copies. Also the required large computing power will no longer be a serious obstacle in the near future. A problem still remaining is the construction of a user interface that allows the easy and natural access to the exploration tools.

div.head: (See wlor plates, p. CP-15.)
div.p: Both the implemented knowledge and the exploration tools are only a subset of what can be imagined. In addition the spatial resolution achieved with MRI is not yet sufficient for all applications.

Nonetheless the pilot project has shown that a volume model based approach is superior t o nonvolume based atlas techniques, because it allows the user t o choose according t o his needs a virtually infinite number of "views" of the anatomy to be explored. Thus the approach comprises the presently used atlas techniques in that it allows the generation of pictures in a form needed for both books and hypermedia documents. For this purpose further image material like photographic images of cross-sections as representations for the real appearance, or Positron-Emission Tomography (PET) for functional aspects have t o be included. Their inclusion is not a problem in computer science, but a practical problem of data acquisition. This aspect is addressed in the "visible human" project [23]. Beyond atlas generation our approach even allows the generation of solid models, for example by using stereolithography. For the necessary conversion of the volume data into a surface representation we use the marching cubes algorithm [24]. For general use, of course, the data base contents still have t o be refined, which should only be a matter of time. Thus we believe that 3D medical atlasses of the described kind will be state of the art in the near future. Fig. 7 Pelvic surgery atlas: The appearance of complicated fractures in cross-sectional images can be interactively explored.

figure.figDesc: Overview of the basic data structure here filled with knowledge concerning brain.

topology (e. g. thalamus is next to the third ventricle) , 0 function (e. g. an sensory stimulus goes through spinothalamic tract) , 0 blood supply (e. g. internal carotid artery supplies anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery) Fig. 2 View into the knowledge base showing the definition of objects, their relations, and their visualization parameters.

figure.head: Fig. 3
figure.figDesc: User interface of the atlas system showing a view of the brain model The tools for the exploration of thus represented with interactively generated cuts and annot at ions. models may be divided in four groups: visualization, composition, interrogation, and simulation.For the visualization it is an advantage of a universal data structure of the volume model that there are virtually no restrictions as to the kind of visualization. The user can choose among the following tools (all described in [22]): 0 remove objects 0 exclude objects from dissection 0 include objects for dissection, and voxel based surface rendering 0 show objects involved in a certain function. cutting (also multiple and irregular cuts) selective cutting (=exclusion of objects from cutting) transparent visualization (X-ray or volume rendering) or meaningful combinations of the above. In'the interrogation phase, according to the location of the cursor on the visible surface new images or symbolic output may be created. Examples for new images are: 0 coloring the corresponding object 0 coloring parent regionsIn the composition mode components may be displayed according t o conditions concerning the object descriptions in the knowledge base. Examples are:0 removing an object 0 adding an object with a certain relation to the selected one (e. g. in front).

div.head: Acknowledgement
div.p: We are grateful to Professor Richter (Dept. of Pediatric Radiology) and Dr. Wening (Dept. of Traumatology) for valuable cooperation. We thank Christian Seebode for practical help. The original MRI image sequence from which the 3D-Atlas has been generated has been kindly provided by Siemens Medical Systems (Erlangen). We are indebted t o the Werner-Otto-Stiftung, Hamburg, which has supported this work in part.
